thread.title: Millburn High School girls tennis team extends state title streak
thread.title_full: Millburn High School girls tennis team extends state title streak

title: Millburn High School girls tennis team extends state title streak
text:
Millburn High School girls tennis team extends state title streak October 16, 2015 Last updated: Friday, October 16, 2015, 11:07 AM By Jim Connelly staff photo by jim connelly 
Editor's note: This is an update of an article first posted on Oct. 15, 2015. 
The streak continues. 
Millburn High School's varsity girls tennis team extended its run of group championships to 10 this afternoon with a 4-1 defeat of Moorestown High School in the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association Group 3 final at Mercer County Park in West Windsor. 
The title run is the second longest in state history, trailing only Red Bank Catholic High School's mark of 11 in a row from 1982 to 1993. 
Millburn, with the victory, claimed its 21st group title, snapping a tie with Haddonfield Memorial High School for the most group crowns in state history. 
Stephanie Schrage of Millburn recorded the match's first point with a 6-0, 6-0 win at first singles over Emily O'Neil. 
The second doubles team of Elizabeth Gray and Anna Mandel extended Millburn's lead to 2-0 with a 6-0, 6-1 triumph at second doubles against Sarah Mainzer and Maddie Sherman. 
Milburn's Alex Pritsker provided the title clinching point with a 6-1, 6-3 defeat of Alex Boone at second singles. 
Joanna Atwater gave Millburn a 4-0 lead with a 7-6 (7-5) 6-2 defeat of Anna Mary Shetler at third singles. 
With the outcome of the match no longer in doubt, the first doubles match went to a third set super tiebreaker. 
Moorestown's Camila Hozdevila and Andrea Giacobbo edged Isabella Waung and Sydney Zirlin 3-6, 6-2, 10-6. 
Millburn now advances to next week's six-team NJSIAA Tournament of Champions, where it will attempt to win a third straight title. 
If it accomplishments that feat, the Millers will tie Super Essex Conference rival Newark Academy for the most T of C crowns, eight. 
See the Thursday, Oct. 22, 2015, print edition of The Item of Millburn and Short Hills for more details.
